qas.question: What beverage is consumed by more people in Kathmandu, coffee or tea?
How might a western traveler find the tea served in Kathmandu?
What is used to make thwon?
What goes through a fermentation process to create tongba?

context: Kathmandu has a larger proportion of <a0_0>tea<a0_0/> drinkers than coffee drinkers. Tea is widely served but is <a1_0>extremely weak<a1_0/> by western standards. It is richer and contains tea leaves boiled with milk, sugar and spices. Alcohol is widely drunk, and there are numerous local variants of alcoholic beverages. Drinking and driving is illegal, and authorities have a zero tolerance policy. Ailaa and thwon (alcohol made from <a2_0>rice<a2_0/>) are the alcoholic beverages of Kathmandu, found in all the local bhattis (<a3_0>alcohol serving eateries<a3_0/>). Chhyaang, tongba (fermented <a4_0>millet or barley<a4_0/>) and rakshi are alcoholic beverages from other parts of Nepal which are found in Kathmandu. However, shops and bars in Kathmandu widely sell western and Nepali beers.
